description: First time I installed this package, it crashed on login (to BitWarden) and would only sit and spin infinitely there-after. When removing (via Discover) I was prompted to remove associated data too. When I did that and re-installed, everything simply worked the second time around.

I recently switched from Windows to Ubuntu (privacy issues) and I am pleased with BitWarden's Windows performance, I am less impressed with its Linux/Android performance.
	The SNAP version siply won't work, even when I invooke the Password-manager-service via the command line. The Flatpak version, so far, seems OK and with no post install permissions stuff.
	The Android version is extremely unstable.(Lenovo M10 3rd gen)
summary: Bitwarden needs to step up its Linux/Android game

description:
Every time I try and use the SNAP package, the app tells me the 2FA code that's just been emailed to me is invalid. I either get a message to say the token is invalid or one relating to decode and JWT.
The AppImage works just fine on the same Kubuntu 22.04 deployment. So the rating it just for a SNAP and not Bitwarden in general

It needs some help to work. It keeps in login all the time until I run the next:

https://bitwarden.com/help/getting-started-desktop/#tab-3-6vQUhrVotSKFarA3cqyESG

The Bitwarden Password Manager desktop app uses secure storage for persisting authentication tokens while you are logged in to the application. If you use Snap to install the desktop app, you will need to allow the app to access secure storage by:

 1.-  On all distributions, run the command sudo snap connect bitwarden:password-manager-service.

 2.- If you've already logged in to the Password Manager desktop app, log out of all accounts and log back in.
summary: Not working without a little help

It sucks. It won't load the vault. Just keeps saying error importing vault data. Funny, I can access it just fine in my browser. 5/5 if it ever works, as of right now all it's done is munch my credentials and 2fa and give back nothing. Concerning.

description:
Bitwarden requires access to the password-manager-service for secure storage. Please enable it through permissions or by running:

sudo snap connect bitwarden:password-manager-service.

summary: Worked for a good while then didn't???

description: I couldn't find the key I stored in this app, but I could find the key on browser plugin.

I never really felt comfortable with either LastPass or Keepass, as the former was run by a company of questionable reliability and the latter implemented some custom encryption and didn't see much maintainership.

One of the main draws of an open source solution to password management is the ability to take a peek at the code yourself, and in this case to run the server component yourself. I haven't taken advantage of the latter, but having a software engineering background in web technologies I did take a look at the code of the browser extension and was pleased to see the use of modern libsodium-based browser APIs and an overall very clean codebase (important for understanding and auditing). I wouldn't call it anywhere near a complete audit, but it increases my confidence that the data really is handled securely.

For a serious audit, it has gone through third party review recently (with results posted on their blog here: https://blog.bitwarden.com/bitwarden-completes-third-party-security-audit-c1cc81b6d33) and they have a bug bounty program on top of that.

This desktop app works very well if you need to sift through credentials manually for server logins, desktop programs and the like, but I highly encourage checking out the browser extensions as well (if you use Brave, Chrom(e|ium) or Firefox).
summary: Fast, flexible, and I'm much more confident in the open security model

description: Having used both snap as well as flatpak, I can absolutely feel the difference

I use Linux, macOS, iOS and Windows and need a solution that works across all my platforms.

Awsome application!
Not open scource

If selfhosting isn't yours, they provide an server themselves.
One of the best if not THE best password managers available.

This is by far the best Password Manager you can get. Not to mention it is free. I have been using pretty much all of the top Password Managers on the market, paid also, and Bitwarden does not dissapoint when compared to the rest. 
Highly recommend.

I love Bitwarden. It is reliable and fast, and I am able to add passwords in groups for my family to use (this is a paid feature). The Flatpak implementation is wonderful.

I have been using KeePass / KeePassXC for many years. But syncing between a multitude of devices with different operating systems (Linux, MacOS, Windows, Android) was always a pain. Until I found this one.

description: Easy to use. Make sure that the desktop install uses the same username that you created as the one you create on their web site.

description: Just works well. It doesn't have a workflow as smooth as KeepassX. Using the native app, KeepassX can directly open a website by a short-cut key and copy-paste both username and password into the browser. Here for Bitwerden, you need to have an extension for that. And again, it requires several clicks to do that. Workflow needs improvements. GUI is handsome. Rest everything OK.
Open source, intuitive, feature rich, native Linux support. What else could you ask for?

Solid password manager, and great that it's open source. My one nitpick is that it's not integrated into the desktop at all; it just lives in its own little window and requires you to open and unlock it every time you want to grab a password, which makes the whole process a bit slow.

I was looking for a password manager that works in multiple OS's and can synchronize and share passwords with family members.

The paid option includes great features like password sharing and 2FA.

Now my family uses it all the time, which proofs how easy to use Bitwarden is when people above 60 with little computer experience rapidly understand and learn to use Bitwarden password manager.
It's open source, thoroughly peer reviewed, stable, reliable and has both free and paid options for both cloud and self-hosted. It doesn't get better than this.
Awesome piece of software to protect and store your passwords and identity. Also recommend using their browser extension available in firefox store.
it work across platformws as charm , i've been using it since last year and i doubt to let it go any time soon what so ever , fantastic app

simple. with dark modus and a lot of options. good security and privacy. Usable even with a free account.

Then you just click the extension to see the list of accounts, click the one you want and it fills all the fields for you. The only con is I waited too long to start using it. summary: A fantastic cross-platform password & secrets manager

description: Like bitwarden.

There is constant checking for new passwords to see if that password has been flagged at any time, anywhere. You can set how many of special characters [i.e. at least 2], Capital, lowercase, and yep, Numbers too. With all those filters in place, you can sit there for an hour or a few seconds (entirely your choice, you understand) clicking for a new combination, and another, and so on. Oh, almost forgot, you can set how long or short it is as well. And BACKUPS? There are backed up backups to ensure you NEVER forget your entry code. It has autofill, and if your phone (or computer) has fingerprint ID, it works for that as well. And it is user-friendly and easy. But never a compromise. AND THAT is just the free version! Yeah, 5 Stars, for sure.
summary: Bitwarden. There is no substitute. [Seriously! Allow me to explain...]

description: Password manager on steroids but still easy to use.

Bitwarden has become a favourite among the privacy community thanks to its open source nature, it's large array of features, the ability so self-host, reasonable cost, and its cross-device sync functionality. I highly recommend it to anybody looking for a reliable and trustworthy password manager.

https://lecrabeinfo.net/utiliser-bitwarden-gestionnaire-mots-de-passe-gratuit-et-open-source.html

Application OpenSource, avec des clients multiplateformes. Qui fonctionne sans pépin depuis maintenant 1 an que je l'utilise.

Open-Source, multi-plateformes, multi-lingue, facile à utiliser.

Ça soulage d'un poids, ça change la vie. En plus, c'est simple d'utilisation.
je l'utilise depuis 1 an....je n'ai plus de soucis ..juste retenir le mot de passe maitre...

J'ai essayé plusieurs gestionnaires de mots de passe ces dernières années. J'ai longtemps utilisé Dashlane. Puis cherchant à remplacer les logiciels et applications que j'utilise pour des solutions Open Source, j'ai mis la main sur BitWarden. Il est mon gestionnaire par défaut depuis 6 mois et je ne suis pas déçu. Je paie l'abonnement annuel (un minuscule montant de 10 $CAN) pour encourager les développeurs.

Seule suggestion : intégrer à l'application (Linux ou mobile) les outils Premium liés à la sécurité offerts sur la version Web (les différents rapports sur les mots de passe exposés, faibles, faisant partie des fuites de données, etc.).
summary: Remplace gratuitement des ténors du marché

description: Bitwarden est super. Je passe sur une offre payant pour soutenir l'open source.
Pratique, simple et effiucace. Merci!
ergonomique, efficace la meilleure !!

BitWarden est un logiciel simple d'utilisation. Même si l'interface parait pas très attirant, le fait de l'utiliser régulièrement sans y porter attention, ne dérange pas.
Pouvoir générer des mots de passes, ou vérifié si ils ont fuités, est très utile aussi.
Et qu'il soit gratuit, open source, donc pas de risque de virus (même si j'utilise une distribution de linux), je suis totalement satisfait, et je regrettes pas de l'utiliser.

J'utilise Bitwarden sur firefox depuis plusieurs années, et j'en suis très satisfait: il sait se faire oublier et rend des vrais services. J'ai la version locale depuis quelques mois sur ubuntu 20.04 et c'est un complément intéressant pour gérer ses données de connexion et qui fonctionne parfaitement également.

Vous l'aurez compris, je recommande !
Il fait son job. C'est tout ce que je lui demande ;-)
summary: Bon gestionnaire de mots de passe

description:
Je l'utilise en extension de Firefox, et je l'ai installé sur mon "téléphone intelligent" (un smartphone quoi), j'ai toujours mes mots de passe à jour en respectant la procédure d'enregistrement. Le meilleur gestionnaire de mots de passe, la fin des soucis. 
Dire qu'il y a encore des gens qui notent leurs mots de passe dans un carnet! 
Faites connaître Bitwarden à tout le monde, cette appli est d'utilité publique.

La version desktop permet de plus facilement naviguer et éditer les informations reprises dans le gestionnaire de mot de passe.
Après plusieurs annéees d'utilisation, je n'ai rien à redire en dehors de la lenteur au lancement et de l'absence de vérification de la sécurité en dehors du coffre-fort/vault, deux points qui ne gachent en rien l'utilisation (simple et agréable) de Bitwarden desktop.

the developper update the snap alomost at the same time as their binary version ( windows, appimage) This is wonderful.

It works very well on Ubuntu.

Лучший! Хотя бы потому, что работает и в Linux, и в Windows.
Позитивчика всееем! ✌️😁

На гитхабе разаработчик описал решение проблемы из которой пароли не отображаются при запуске Bitwarden
_______________________________________________________________________

Всем привет, спасибо за отчеты! В этом выпуске мы перешли на хранение наших токенов в безопасном хранилище, но, к сожалению, пакеты snap изолированы, и мы не можем автоматически включить доступ к password-manager-service разрешению. Если вы столкнулись с этой проблемой, есть пара исправлений:

Программное обеспечение Ubuntu> Установлено> Bitwarden> Разрешения - включите "Чтение, добавление, изменение или удаление сохраненных паролей"
Запустите следующее: sudo snap connect bitwarden:password-manager-service
Пожалуйста, обязательно выйдите из системы и снова войдите в нее после включения этого разрешения. Если у вас возникнут какие-либо проблемы, пожалуйста, не стесняйтесь обращаться, спасибо!

Хорошее приложение для тех, кто привык пользоваться данным сервисом. Еще месяц назад в версии 23.10 всё работало. Мигрировал на 24.04. Приложение запускается, но после ввода мастер-пароля на этапе входа данные хранилища не отображаются в приложении. И пока проблема решения не имеет.
ни appimage c офф сайта ни snap пакеты прост оне работают после ввода пароля, хотя все тоже самое работает прекрасно на NEON и Ubuntu 22.04

С 1 апреля перестал синхронизировать записи, а если быть точным - не синхронизирует ничего и не дает посмотреть текущие записи. Обновлений нет, фикса проблемы нет, разрабы bitwarden'а отписываются что "флетпаки ваши нами не поддерживаются", в общем красота..
